course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Logic
course.description: This course is designed to provide the students with the basic knowledge of logic, so that they can apply logical techniques to analyze various problems of reasoning in ordinary language and to examine the fallacies of thinking in daily life. The course includes topics such as the basic concepts of logic, logic and language, fallacies and definitions, sentential logic, and syllogism.

reviews.author: gazelle
reviews.title: The best professor I have ever encountered since my 4 years of study.
reviews.comment_content:
According to the course description, HUMA 1720 is an introduction to formal philosophical logic, a systematic study of arguments for internal cogency. Course content could be divided into 3 main parts:

1. Basics in logic (e.g. validity, soundness, inferences, fallacies, sentential logic symbolisation, etc.)
2. Sentential logic derivations
3. Predicate logic symbolisation and derivations

Grading scheme:
Attendance — 5%
Term test 1 — 15%  (covers 1 only)
Term test 2 — 20%  (covers 2 only)
Term test 3 — 20%  (covers 3 only)
Final exam — 40%  (covers 1, 2 & 3)

I would say 1 & 2 is rather straightforward, everyone should be able to do well. The most difficult part of this course is predicate logic symbolisation. Not only because of it being conceptually difficult, but also one can easily make mistakes with incautiousness. While predicate logic derivation is slightly less intellectually demanding.

FYI, course content of HUMA 1720 is more or less overlapped with some MATH/COMP courses. A friend of mine lent me his notes of COMP 2711 and I realised 70-80% of the logic stuff is similar to that of HUMA 1720.

I have heard that HUMA 1720 offered few years ago didn’t even cover predicate logic. This means we have already learnt sufficiently more than students of few years ago, although the course doesn’t really cover quantifier ordering in depth.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Every lecture is well structured with clear focus and carefully selected examples. This can be proven by merely listening to 20-30 mins of William’s presentation. I literally found no reason skipping his lecture, not even for a single lecture.

It is praiseworthy that lecture materials are designed in a professional, user-friendly manner, which effectively enhances our understanding of the content. This is in stark contrast to most UST courses where course content is blurred by messy slides and professors’ disastrous articulation. And these also explain why students tend to skip lectures and self-educate.

However, I observed that William tends to complicate things, especially when demonstrating sentential and predicate logic derivations. There are indeed “shortcuts” that allow you solve the problems faster, but it seems he seldom uses. I guess because he understands logic far better and deeper than us, and he simply cannot think as simple and straightforward as we students do.

This is sometimes a good practice, since problems in advanced logic are often counter-intuitive. I remember once I raised questions about predicate logic symbolisation. It turns out that I oversimplified that problem, in that it is related to quantifier ordering which the course doesn’t really cover.

Despite imperfection, I would still give William an A+ for his teaching (even an A is underrated from my perspective). At the very least he knows what he is doing, and we also know what he is doing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Decent. I received an A+ with a total score of 93.33%, given the maximum of 99.23%. Not even HUMA 1000A could give me such a high grade. You can do good in this course without prior logic/linguistic training, just like me.

I originally thought that I could at most get an A- — I only got 87.5% in the final exam because of my careless mistakes in predicate logic symbolisation, and my inability to solve the hardest predicate logic derivation.

You know, cut off score of an A is 94% for some bad grade courses, meaning 90.00-93.99% is still an A-. So, I would say William is really generous in giving out the grade. As a matter of fact, he once said he is impressed by our outstanding performance in assessments.

I guess performance during lecture does help as well. I often ask difficult questions when William introduces new things. And he somehow manages to answer in a logical, succinct manner, demonstrating his strong knowledge foundation and illustrating the peculiarity of logic as a discipline. Probably this leaves him with a deep impression.

I also remember once he said he has had a student who gave a short, ingenious derivation in term test 3. And that student was me XDD. It is great that he did understand what I have written, I originally thought that I flunked out.
reviews.comment_workload:
Reasonable. Hard work does pay off, as long as you work hard on the right track.

You can ace the term tests and final exam by merely studying the lecture notes and supplementary exercises prepared by William. You don’t need to recite any definitions nor explanations, as there would be no MCQs nor T/Fs.

You need to ensure you have a deep understanding of those materials, rather than aimlessly having lots and lots of practice, especially for predicate logic derivation. The aim of practice, after all, is to solidify what you have learnt.

The practice problems you have seen in Logic 2010, reading materials, or even online sources are at most considered “seemingly complicated”. What you will see during term tests and exam, comparatively, are “conceptually hard” — something strange that you have never encountered before.

If you don’t know how to do it, no matter how many questions you have practiced and how much time is allowed, you still don’t know how to do it. Luckily, with use of the techniques learnt from lecture, you could at least solve some of them and still do good in the end.

reviews.author: polar
reviews.title: A nice course to learn logic and derivation
reviews.comment_content:
The course can be divided into 3 parts. After teaching one part, we have a term test to examine our knowledge in that part.
1. Validity, Inferences, Fallacies, and Sentential Logic Symbolisation
2. Sentential Logic Derivation
3. Predicate Logic Symbolisation and Derivation

If you have learnt discrete maths before (e.g. COMP2711), you already know a lot of topics covered in part 1 and part 2. Even you don't know any discrete maths, it is not hard for you to catch up. In fact, many students get full marks in the first term test. For sentential logic derivation, I would suggest reading the textbook if you find it unclear in the lecture notes.
The hardest part of this course is predicate logic. Spend more time on this topic if you want to get a good result in the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor is Dr T.Y. William Wong. He is new to HKUST.
We have online lectures this semester.

During the lecture, William tries his best to explain the topics. Occasionally, he may confuse himself and may not be able to answer questions right away, but he manages to answer it via email with an informative and detailed explanation. I enjoy his lectures. I believe it would be more interesting if we have face-to-face lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading.

Grading Scheme:
Term Test 1 (15%): Mean: 46.3
Term Test 2 (20%): Mean: 49;  SD: 10.44
Term Test 3 (20%): Mean: 41.8
Final Exam  (40%): Mean: 77.7
Attendance  (5%)

I got full marks in term test 1 and almost full marks in term test 2.
I am above the mean in term test 3 and around the mean in the final exam.
I attended all lectures.

Total: 87.6 => A
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. You don't have to submit any homework. You just need to attend all lectures and revise for the tests and the exam by doing exercise. If you have prior experience in discrete maths, the workload will be even smaller since you already have a good foundation.

reviews.author: ip
reviews.title: Excellent course
reviews.comment_teaching:
The prof himself is passionate in logic. His lecture ppts are easy to follow and he explains concepts clearly. He puts difficult questions on ppts which is good for our practice.

The tutors are very responsive. Thanks to the tutors, I was able to clear some confusion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is super nice, best grading in HKUST. I got above mean for the first two quizzes, around mean for the third one, and below mean for final exam. Still able to secure an A-.

Don't worry if you are not from engineering. I am not, and am weak in math. I still manage to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: As the quizzes are spread throughout the semester, please expect some workload for self revision.

Sentential/propositional logic
Quiz 2
Syllogisms

Predicate Logic

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is ok. Leo will demonstrate a lot of examples to help us understand.

Quiz1:20%
Quiz2:20%
Quiz3:20%
Quiz4:20%
Essay:20%

Mean:
Quiz1: 17.6/20
Quiz2: 18.5/20
Quiz3: 14.7/20
Quiz4: 14/20
Essay: 16/20

Quiz 1 and Quiz 2 two quizzes are easy.
Quiz 3 and Quiz 4 are much difficult. Need to revise the tutorial notes and do as much as exercise you can. In the tutorial, TA will give you tips about the quizzes which are useful.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 4 quizzes and 1 essay. Just do the tutorial notes and the exercises in the lecture notes and you will be fine in the quizzes.

Essay only 300-400 words. And most of them use logic symbols. So do not need to worry write a lot of things. 1-2 pages should be fine.
